introduction.content: Polygenic risk scores (PRS), which quantify the genetic risk for traits from common variants, have improved in their predictive performances over the past decade [1] . Building on classical approaches of pruning and thresholding, methods incorporating Bayesian approaches using prior knowledge about genetic architecture, relatedness of individuals, linkage disequilibrium patterns, and genetic effects across populations have improved the assignment of variant weights and PRS performance [2] , [3] , [4] , [5] . In parallel, genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have continued to expand in size, with the most recent iteration of the GWASs for human height and coronary artery disease reaching 5.4 million and 1.3 million participants, respectively [6] , [7] . The incorporation of multi-ancestry and multi-trait GWAS data has further improved PRS prediction in diverse ancestral groups [8] . In attempting to quantify total inherited risk, each of these PRS iterations for a given trait captures unique information contingent on source GWAS, method, and training dataset. PRS are increasingly being delivered to patients. Third-party genetic testing companies and healthcare system laboratories are already delivering polygenic scores for coronary artery disease, diabetes, cancers, and other diseases [9] , [10] . The eMERGE consortium has developed PRS reports for 10 diseases to return to participants within the healthcare system as part of a larger effort to study genomic risk assessment and management [11] , [12] , [13] . Furthermore, researchers recently developed clinically valid assays, clinical workflows, and patient- and physician-oriented information materials to accompany PRS reports delivered within the Mass General Brigham Biobank and the Veterans Affairs Genomic Medicine at Veterans Affairs (GenoVA) Study [14] , [15] . New clinical trials are incorporating PRS into medical decision-making (NCT05819814, NCT05850091), and medical societies have begun to release initial statements on their utility [16] , [17] . Although consistency in risk classification is important for clinical decision-making, risk prediction models for complex diseases will inherently have variability in high-risk classification. These differences often stem from differences in training population, outcome definition, and underlying statistical methodology. Even though different risk prediction models may be correlated at their mean, extreme value theory suggests they are inherently likely to differ in classifying risk in the extremes [18] . The introduction of new models often leads to significant reclassification of high-risk risk among patients, raising questions about the need for altering recommendations for interventions or therapies. For example, since 2013, the American College of Cardiology and the American Heart Association (AHA) have recommended using the Pooled Cohort Equations (PCE) [19] to estimate the 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, but the AHA recently developed the Predicting Risk of CVD EVENTs (PREVENT) equations [20] , which include kidney measures, exclude race, and include heart failure in the composite predicted outcome. When applied to representative cohorts, PREVENT predicts lower cardiovascular risk than PCE and could reclassify about half of US adults to lower risk categories, potentially leading to reduced statin and antihypertensive treatment eligibility and increasing incidence of composite cardiovascular outcomes [21] . Similarly, current reports of polygenic risk also provide a categorical assessment of high risk, and different studies and companies use different scores for the same traits [9] , [10] , [11] . As advances in GWAS size and statistical methods continue to fuel the release of improved new PRS, a framework is needed for updating scores or incorporating new data without causing confusion. Despite ongoing progress toward clinical implementation, the variability of individual-level classification of ‘high genetic risk’ using different PRS for a given trait remains largely untested, and consensus PRS for any trait currently does not exist. Previous efforts have focused on population-level prediction metrics, rather than consistency of high-risk classification presented in individual clinical reports now as a part of clinical implementation workflows [8] . Prior limited availability of large holdout diverse datasets has precluded individual-level benchmarking to assess agreement in classification between PRS. Furthermore, there is a need to aggregate and incorporate orthogonal data from available PRS while overcoming the correlation between scores and maximize predictive performance. In this work, we use the large and ancestrally-diverse All of Us (AOU) cohort [22] to compare the classification of individuals with high genetic risk based on published polygenic scores for three common, complex diseases: coronary artery disease (CAD), type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), and major depressive disorder (MDD). We also test the effect of using PRSmix [23] — a tool that agnostically integrates information across several PRS for a given trait to improve prediction accuracy for a target population — in influencing high genetic risk classification over iterations of polygenic scores. We find extreme disagreement regarding individual-level high-risk classification between published scores and observe how integrative scoring via PRSmix mitigates this instability.

sentences.sentence: Polygenic risk scores (PRS), which quantify the genetic risk for traits from common variants, have improved in their predictive performances over the past decade [1].

1.2: Polygenic scores integrate information from many common sites of DNA variation into a single number.
1.3: Rapid increases in the scale of genetic association studies have enabled the development of polygenic scores.
1.4: New statistical algorithms have enabled the development of polygenic scores.
1.5: Polygenic scores developed with new statistical algorithms meaningfully measure risk of coronary artery disease as early as birth.
1.6: Newer-generation polygenic scores identify up to 8% of the population with triple the normal risk based on genetic variation alone.
1.7: Individuals identified by polygenic scores with increased risk cannot be identified based on family history alone.
1.8: Individuals identified by polygenic scores with increased risk cannot be identified based on clinical risk factors alone.
1.9: Evidence supports risk reduction for individuals identified with increased genetic risk using adherence to a healthy lifestyle.
1.10: Evidence supports risk reduction for individuals identified with increased genetic risk using cholesterol-lowering therapies.
1.11: Adherence to a healthy lifestyle can substantially reduce risk for individuals with increased genetic risk.
1.12: Cholesterol-lowering therapies can substantially reduce risk for individuals with increased genetic risk.
1.13: There is considerable enthusiasm for the potential of polygenic risk estimation to enable a new era of preventive clinical medicine.
1.14: There is recognition of a need for ongoing research to ensure equitable performance of polygenic scores across diverse ancestries.
1.15: There is recognition of a need for ongoing research into how to assess polygenic scores in clinical practice.
1.16: There is recognition of a need for ongoing research into whom to assess with polygenic scores in clinical practice.
1.17: There is a need for randomized trials to confirm the clinical utility of polygenic scores.

viewpoints: Polygenic risk scores quantify the genetic risk for traits from common genetic variants.
The predictive performance of polygenic risk scores has improved over the past decade.

sentences.sentence: Building on classical approaches of pruning and thresholding, methods incorporating Bayesian approaches using prior knowledge about genetic architecture, relatedness of individuals, linkage disequilibrium patterns, and genetic effects across populations have improved the assignment of variant weights and PRS performance [2], [3], [4], [5].

3.1: Linear mixed models are a powerful statistical tool for identifying genetic associations.
3.2: Linear mixed models are a powerful statistical tool for avoiding confounding.
3.3: Existing methods of linear mixed models are computationally intractable in large cohorts.
3.4: Existing methods of linear mixed models may not optimize power.
3.5: All existing methods require a time cost of O(MN(2)), where N is the number of samples and M is the number of SNPs.
3.6: Existing methods implicitly assume an infinitesimal genetic architecture in which effect sizes are normally distributed.
3.7: An infinitesimal genetic architecture, where effect sizes are normally distributed, can limit power.
3.8: BOLT-LMM is a far more efficient mixed-model association method.
3.9: BOLT-LMM requires only a small number of O(MN) time iterations.
3.10: BOLT-LMM increases power by modeling more realistic, non-infinitesimal genetic architectures.
3.11: BOLT-LMM uses a Bayesian mixture prior on marker effect sizes to model more realistic genetic architectures.
3.12: BOLT-LMM was applied to 9 quantitative traits in 23,294 samples from the Women's Genome Health Study (WGHS).
3.13: Significant increases in power were observed when applying BOLT-LMM, consistent with simulations.
3.14: Theory shows that the boost in power from BOLT-LMM increases with cohort size.
3.15: Simulations show that the boost in power from BOLT-LMM increases with cohort size.
3.16: The increase in power with cohort size makes BOLT-LMM appealing for genome-wide association studies in large cohorts.

4.1: Polygenic risk scores (PRS) perform poorly in predicting genetic risk across different populations.
4.2: Existing genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have been conducted predominantly in individuals of European descent.
4.3: The limited transferability of polygenic risk scores (PRS) reduces their clinical value in non-European populations.
4.4: The limited transferability of polygenic risk scores (PRS) may exacerbate healthcare disparities.
4.5: Recent efforts have been made to level ancestry imbalance in genomic research.
4.6: Recent efforts have expanded the scale of non-European genome-wide association studies (GWAS).
4.7: Most non-European genome-wide association studies (GWAS) remain underpowered.
4.8: A new PRS construction method called PRS-CSx is presented.
4.10: PRS-CSx integrates GWAS summary statistics from multiple populations.
4.11: PRS-CSx couples genetic effects across populations via a shared continuous shrinkage (CS) prior.
4.12: PRS-CSx enables more accurate effect size estimation by sharing information between summary statistics.
4.13: PRS-CSx leverages linkage disequilibrium diversity across discovery samples.
4.14: PRS-CSx inherits computational efficiency from PRS-CS.
4.16: PRS-CSx outperforms alternative methods across traits with a wide range of genetic architectures in simulations.
4.17: PRS-CSx outperforms alternative methods across traits with cross-population genetic overlaps in simulations.
4.18: PRS-CSx outperforms alternative methods with different discovery GWAS sample sizes in simulations.
4.19: PRS-CSx improves the prediction of quantitative traits in non-European populations.
4.20: PRS-CSx improves the prediction of schizophrenia risk in non-European populations.

6.2: Identifying the specific variants and associated regions of SNPs that explain phenotypic variation in human height requires huge sample sizes.

20.1: Primary prevention guidelines recommend the use of multivariable equations to assess absolute risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD).
20.2: Current equations for assessing absolute risk of cardiovascular disease have several limitations.

20.7: The primary outcome for developing the PREVENT equations was cardiovascular disease.
20.8: The primary outcome for developing the PREVENT equations included atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease and heart failure.
20.9: Predictors for the PREVENT equations included traditional risk factors, such as smoking status, systolic blood pressure, cholesterol levels, and antihypertensive or statin use.
20.10: The estimated glomerular filtration rate was included as a predictor in the PREVENT equations.
20.11: Diabetes was included as a predictor in the PREVENT equations.
20.12: The models for the PREVENT equations were sex-specific.
20.13: The models for the PREVENT equations were race-free.
20.14: The models for the PREVENT equations were developed on the age scale.
20.15: The models for the PREVENT equations were adjusted for competing risk of non-cardiovascular disease death.
20.16: Analyses for developing the PREVENT equations were conducted in each data set.
20.17: The results of analyses from each data set were meta-analyzed.
20.18: Discrimination for the PREVENT equations was assessed using the Harrell C-statistic.
20.19: Calibration for the PREVENT equations was calculated as the slope of the observed versus predicted risk by decile.
20.20: Additional equations were developed to predict each cardiovascular disease subtype, including atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease and heart failure.
20.21: Optional predictors, including urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio and hemoglobin A1c, were included in the additional equations.
20.22: The social deprivation index was included in the additional equations.
20.23: External validation of the PREVENT equations was conducted with 3,330,085 participants.
20.24: External validation used 21 additional data sets.
20.25: A total of 6,612,004 adults were included in the study for the PREVENT equations.
20.26: The mean±SD age of the adults included was 53±12 years.
20.27: 56% of the adults included in the study were women.
20.28: The follow-up period had a mean±SD of 4.8±3.1 years.
20.29: There were 211,515 incident total cardiovascular disease events during the follow-up period.
20.30: In the external validation for cardiovascular disease, the median C-statistic for female participants was 0.794 (interquartile interval, 0.763-0.809).
20.31: In the external validation for cardiovascular disease, the median C-statistic for male participants was 0.757 (interquartile interval, 0.727-0.778).
20.32: The calibration slope among female participants was 1.03 (interquartile interval, 0.81-1.16).
20.33: The calibration slope among male participants was 0.94 (interquartile interval, 0.81-1.13).
20.34: Similar estimates for discrimination and calibration were observed for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease-specific models.
20.35: Similar estimates for discrimination and calibration were observed for heart failure-specific models.
20.36: The improvement in discrimination was small but statistically significant when the urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio, hemoglobin A1c, and social deprivation index were added to the base model for total cardiovascular disease.
20.37: The ΔC-statistic for discrimination improvement among female participants was 0.004 [0.004-0.005].
20.38: The ΔC-statistic for discrimination improvement among male participants was 0.005 [0.004-0.007].
20.39: Calibration improved significantly when the urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio was added to the base model for individuals with marked albuminuria (>300 mg/g).
20.40: The calibration slope with the base model for marked albuminuria was 1.05 [0.84-1.20] compared to 1.39 [1.14-1.65] when the urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio was added.
20.41: The PREVENT equations accurately predicted risk for incident cardiovascular disease and cardiovascular disease subtypes.
20.42: The PREVENT equations precisely predicted risk for incident cardiovascular disease and cardiovascular disease subtypes.
20.43: The PREVENT equations used routinely available clinical variables.
20.44: The PREVENT equations were validated in a large, diverse, and contemporary sample of US adults.

viewpoints: Since 2013, the American College of Cardiology has recommended using the Pooled Cohort Equations to estimate the 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.
Since 2013, the American Heart Association has recommended using the Pooled Cohort Equations to estimate the 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.
The American Heart Association recently developed the Predicting Risk of CVD EVENTs equations.
The Predicting Risk of CVD EVENTs equations include kidney measures.
The Predicting Risk of CVD EVENTs equations exclude race.
The Predicting Risk of CVD EVENTs equations include heart failure in the composite predicted outcome.

sentences.sentence: When applied to representative cohorts, PREVENT predicts lower cardiovascular risk than PCE and could reclassify about half of US adults to lower risk categories, potentially leading to reduced statin and antihypertensive treatment eligibility and increasing incidence of composite cardiovascular outcomes [21].

21.1: Since 2013, the American College of Cardiology (ACC) and American Heart Association (AHA) have recommended the pooled cohort equations (PCEs) for estimating the 10-year risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD).
21.2: An AHA scientific advisory group recently developed the Predicting Risk of cardiovascular disease EVENTs (PREVENT) equations.
21.3: The PREVENT equations incorporated kidney measures.
21.4: The PREVENT equations removed race as an input.
21.5: The PREVENT equations improved calibration in contemporary populations.
21.6: PREVENT is known to produce ASCVD risk predictions that are lower than those produced by the pooled cohort equations (PCEs).
21.7: The potential clinical implications of using PREVENT equations instead of PCEs have not been quantified.
21.8: The intention was to estimate the number of US adults who would experience changes in risk categorization when applying PREVENT equations to existing ACC and AHA guidelines.
21.9: The intention was to estimate the number of US adults who would experience changes in treatment eligibility when applying PREVENT equations to existing ACC and AHA guidelines.
21.10: The intention was to estimate the number of US adults who would experience changes in clinical outcomes when applying PREVENT equations to existing ACC and AHA guidelines.
21.11: A cross-sectional sample of 7765 US adults aged 30 to 79 years was used.
21.12: The sample included participants from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Surveys of 2011 to March 2020.
21.13: The surveys had response rates ranging from 47% to 70%.
21.15: There were differences in predicted 10-year ASCVD risk.
21.16: There were differences in ACC and AHA risk categorization.
21.17: There were differences in eligibility for statin therapy.
21.18: There were differences in eligibility for antihypertensive therapy.
21.19: There were projected differences in occurrences of myocardial infarction.
21.20: There were projected differences in occurrences of stroke.
21.21: In a nationally representative sample of 7765 US adults aged 30 to 79 years, it was estimated that using PREVENT equations would reclassify approximately half of US adults to lower ACC and AHA risk categories.
21.22: Using PREVENT equations would reclassify 53.0% [95% CI, 51.2%-54.8%] of US adults to lower ACC and AHA risk categories.
21.23: Using PREVENT equations would reclassify very few US adults to higher ACC and AHA risk categories.
21.24: PREVENT would reclassify 0.41% [95% CI, 0.25%-0.62%] of US adults to higher ACC and AHA risk categories.
21.25: The median age of the sample was 53 years.
21.27: The number of US adults receiving or recommended for preventive treatment would decrease by an estimated 14.3 million for statin therapy.
21.28: The decrease in the number of US adults for statin therapy has a confidence interval of 95% (12.6 million-15.9 million).
21.29: The number of US adults receiving or recommended for preventive treatment would decrease by an estimated 2.62 million for antihypertensive therapy.
21.30: The decrease in the number of US adults for antihypertensive therapy has a confidence interval of 95% (2.02 million-3.21 million).
21.31: The study estimated that, over 10 years, the decreases in treatment eligibility could result in 107,000 additional occurrences of myocardial infarction or stroke.
21.32: Eligibility changes would affect twice as many men as women.
21.33: Eligibility changes would affect a greater proportion of Black adults than White adults.
21.34: By assigning lower ASCVD risk predictions, the application of the PREVENT equations to existing treatment thresholds could reduce eligibility for statin therapy among 15.8 million US adults.
21.35: The application of the PREVENT equations to existing treatment thresholds could reduce eligibility for antihypertensive therapy among 15.8 million US adults.

viewpoints: When applied to representative cohorts, the PREVENT equations predict lower cardiovascular risk than the Pooled Cohort Equations.
The application of PREVENT equations could reclassify about half of US adults to lower risk categories.
PREVENT reclassification could lead to reduced statin treatment eligibility.
PREVENT reclassification could lead to reduced antihypertensive treatment eligibility.
PREVENT reclassification could increase the incidence of composite cardiovascular outcomes.

sentences.sentence: Similarly, current reports of polygenic risk also provide a categorical assessment of high risk, and different studies and companies use different scores for the same traits [9], [10], [11].

11.1: Polygenic risk scores have improved in predictive performance.
11.2: Several challenges remain to be addressed before polygenic risk scores can be implemented in the clinic.
11.3: The predictive performance of polygenic risk scores is reduced in diverse populations.
11.4: The interpretation and communication of genetic results to both providers and patients are challenges for the implementation of polygenic risk scores in the clinic.
11.5: The National Human Genome Research Institute-funded Electronic Medical Records and Genomics Network has developed a framework to address the challenges of implementing polygenic risk scores in the clinic.
11.6: The National Human Genome Research Institute-funded Electronic Medical Records and Genomics Network has developed a pipeline for return of a PRS-based genome-informed risk assessment.
11.7: The pipeline and framework are being used to return a PRS-based genome-informed risk assessment to 25,000 diverse adults and children as part of a clinical study.
11.8: From an initial list of 23 conditions, ten were selected for implementation based on polygenic risk score performance.
11.9: The selection of conditions for implementation was based on medical actionability.
11.10: The selection of conditions for implementation was based on potential clinical utility.
11.11: The ten selected conditions include cardiometabolic diseases and cancer.
11.12: Standardized metrics were considered in the selection process of conditions for implementation.
11.13: Additional consideration in the selection process was given to the strength of evidence in African populations.
11.14: Additional consideration in the selection process was given to the strength of evidence in Hispanic populations.
11.15: A pipeline for clinical polygenic risk score implementation was developed.
11.16: The pipeline for clinical polygenic risk score implementation includes score transfer to a clinical laboratory.
11.17: The pipeline for clinical polygenic risk score implementation includes validation and verification of score performance.
11.18: Genetic ancestry was used to calibrate polygenic risk score mean and variance.
11.19: Genetically diverse data from 13,475 participants of the All of Us Research Program cohort was utilized to train and test model parameters.
11.20: A framework for regulatory compliance was created.
11.21: A polygenic risk score clinical report was developed for return to providers.
11.22: The polygenic risk score clinical report was developed for inclusion in an additional genome-informed risk assessment.
11.23: The initial experience from the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics Network can inform the approach needed to implement polygenic risk score-based testing in diverse clinical settings.

viewpoints: Current reports of polygenic risk provide a categorical assessment of high risk.
Different studies use different polygenic risk scores for the same traits.
Different companies use different polygenic risk scores for the same traits.

sentences.sentence: As advances in GWAS size and statistical methods continue to fuel the release of improved new PRS, a framework is needed for updating scores or incorporating new data without causing confusion.
viewpoints: Advances in GWAS size continue to fuel the release of improved new polygenic risk scores.
Advances in statistical methods continue to fuel the release of improved new polygenic risk scores.
A framework is needed for updating polygenic risk scores without causing confusion.
A framework is needed for incorporating new data into polygenic risk scores without causing confusion.

sentences.sentence: Despite ongoing progress toward clinical implementation, the variability of individual-level classification of 'high genetic risk' using different PRS for a given trait remains largely untested, and consensus PRS for any trait currently does not exist.
viewpoints: There is ongoing progress toward clinical implementation of polygenic risk scores.
Variability in individual-level classification of 'high genetic risk' using different polygenic risk scores remains largely untested.
A consensus polygenic risk score for any trait currently does not exist.

sentences.sentence: Previous efforts have focused on population-level prediction metrics, rather than consistency of high-risk classification presented in individual clinical reports now as a part of clinical implementation workflows [8].

8.1: There is an important public health need to identify individuals at the highest risk of coronary artery disease.
8.2: It is ideal to identify individuals at the highest risk of coronary artery disease before the onset of the disease.
8.3: Prior studies have developed genome-wide polygenic scores to enable risk stratification for coronary artery disease.
8.4: The development of genome-wide polygenic scores reflects the substantial inherited component of coronary artery disease risk.
8.5: A new and significantly improved polygenic score for coronary artery disease has been developed and is termed GPS.

viewpoints: Previous efforts have focused on population-level prediction metrics.
Previous efforts have not focused on the consistency of high-risk classification in individual clinical reports as part of clinical implementation workflows.

sentences.sentence: Prior limited availability of large holdout diverse datasets has precluded individual-level benchmarking to assess agreement in classification between PRS.
viewpoints: Limited availability of large holdout diverse datasets has precluded individual-level benchmarking.
The lack of benchmarking has prevented assessment of agreement in classification between polygenic risk scores.

sentences.sentence: Furthermore, there is a need to aggregate and incorporate orthogonal data from available PRS while overcoming the correlation between scores and maximize predictive performance.
viewpoints: There is a need to aggregate orthogonal data from available polygenic risk scores.
There is a need to incorporate orthogonal data from available polygenic risk scores.
There is a need to overcome the correlation between polygenic risk scores.
There is a need to maximize predictive performance of polygenic risk scores.

sentences.sentence: In this work, we use the large and ancestrally-diverse All of Us (AOU) cohort [22] to compare the classification of individuals with high genetic risk based on published polygenic scores for three common, complex diseases: coronary artery disease (CAD), type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), and major depressive disorder (MDD).

22.1: Observational cohort studies have provided knowledge that has dramatically advanced the prevention of diseases.
22.2: Observational cohort studies have provided knowledge that has dramatically advanced the treatment of diseases.
22.5: Many observational cohorts do not provide comprehensive phenotype data.
22.6: The All of Us Research Program plans to enroll a diverse group of at least 1 million persons in the United States.
22.7: The purpose of enrolling a diverse group of at least 1 million persons in the United States is to accelerate biomedical research.
22.8: The purpose of enrolling a diverse group of at least 1 million persons in the United States is to improve health.
22.9: The All of Us Research Program aims to make research results accessible to participants.
22.10: The All of Us Research Program is developing new approaches to generate data.
22.11: The All of Us Research Program is developing new approaches to access data.
22.12: The All of Us Research Program is developing new approaches to make data broadly available to approved researchers.
22.13: All of Us opened for enrollment in May 2018.
22.14: All of Us currently enrolls participants who are 18 years of age or older.
22.15: All of Us enrolls participants from a network of more than 340 recruitment sites.
22.16: The program protocol includes health questionnaires.
22.17: The program protocol includes electronic health records (EHRs).
22.18: The program protocol includes physical measurements.
22.19: The program protocol includes the use of digital health technology.
22.20: The program protocol includes the collection and analysis of biospecimens.
22.21: As of July 2019, more than 175,000 participants had contributed biospecimens.
22.22: More than 80% of the participants who contributed biospecimens are from groups that have been historically underrepresented in biomedical research.
22.23: EHR data on more than 112,000 participants have been collected.
22.24: EHR data have been collected from 34 sites.
22.25: The All of Us data repository should permit researchers to take into account individual differences in lifestyle.
22.26: The All of Us data repository should permit researchers to take into account individual differences in socioeconomic factors.
22.27: The All of Us data repository should permit researchers to take into account individual differences in environment.
22.28: The All of Us data repository should permit researchers to take into account individual differences in biologic characteristics.
22.29: Taking into account individual differences in lifestyle, socioeconomic factors, environment, and biologic characteristics aims to advance precision diagnosis.
22.30: Taking into account individual differences in lifestyle, socioeconomic factors, environment, and biologic characteristics aims to advance precision prevention.
22.31: Taking into account individual differences in lifestyle, socioeconomic factors, environment, and biologic characteristics aims to advance precision treatment.

viewpoints: The researchers use the large and ancestrally-diverse All of Us cohort to compare the classification of individuals with high genetic risk.
The comparison is based on published polygenic scores for coronary artery disease.
The comparison is based on published polygenic scores for type 2 diabetes mellitus.
The comparison is based on published polygenic scores for major depressive disorder.

sentences.sentence: We also test the effect of using PRSmix [23] — a tool that agnostically integrates information across several PRS for a given trait to improve prediction accuracy for a target population — in influencing high genetic risk classification over iterations of polygenic scores.

23.1: Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) are an emerging tool.
23.2: Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) are used to predict the clinical phenotypes of individuals.
23.3: Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) are used to predict the outcomes of individuals.
23.4: PRSmix is a proposed framework that leverages the PRS corpus of a target trait to improve prediction accuracy.
23.5: PRSmix+ incorporates genetically correlated traits to better capture the human genetic architecture.
23.6: PRSmix+ is designed for 47 diseases/traits in European ancestries and 32 diseases/traits in South Asian ancestries.
23.7: PRSmix demonstrated a mean prediction accuracy improvement of 1.20-fold.
23.8: The 95% confidence interval for PRSmix's prediction accuracy improvement is [1.10; 1.3].
23.9: The p-value of PRSmix's prediction accuracy improvement is 9.17 × 10.

viewpoints: The researchers test the effect of using PRSmix on high genetic risk classification.
PRSmix is a tool that agnostically integrates information across several polygenic risk scores for a given trait.
PRSmix aims to improve prediction accuracy for a target population.

sentences.sentence: We find extreme disagreement regarding individual-level high-risk classification between published scores and observe how integrative scoring via PRSmix mitigates this instability.
viewpoints: The researchers find extreme disagreement in individual-level high-risk classification between published polygenic risk scores.
Integrative scoring via PRSmix mitigates this instability in high-risk classification.
